justification: “All participants in the DE group exhibited active eating disorder symptoms that are considered severe (as determined by the Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire, 'EDE-Q').”
“Greater binge-eating behavior in DE participants (reported in the last 6 months; EAT-26 questionnaire)…”
“DE participants … restraint behavior, as calculated by EDE-Q subscales…”
“DE participants … higher eating, shape and weight concerns as well as restraint behavior, as calculated by EDE-Q subscales…”
Same sentence notes elevated “shape … concerns,” identified via EDE-Q subscales.
Same sentence refers to higher “weight concerns,” again derived from EDE-Q subscales.
“This included two more questionnaires characterizing eating behavior: the Power of Food Scale (Cappelleri et al., 2009).”

measured_by: Depression Anxiety Stress Scales-21 (DASS-21) – Depression subscale
justification: “Five questionnaires evaluated affective dispositions such as anxiety and depression: the Depression, Anxiety, and Stress Scale-21 ('DASS-21').”
Same list names DASS-21 for assessing anxiety along with depression and stress.
DASS-21 also provides a Stress subscale, cited in the same sentence on affective dispositions.
“Five questionnaires evaluated affective dispositions … the Liebowitz Social Anxiety Scale ('LSAS').”
The same list includes “Obsessive-Compulsive Inventory ('OCI').”
“Behavioral Activation and Behavioral Inhibition Scale ('BIS/BAS': Carver & White, 1994)”—the BIS subscale indexes behavioral inhibition.
The BIS/BAS instrument simultaneously measures behavioral activation through its BAS subscale.
Affective questionnaires list the “Snaith-Hamilton-Pleasure Scale ('SHAPS')” which is widely used to gauge anhedonia.

measured_by: Multidimensional Assessment of Interoceptive Awareness, Version 2 (MAIA-2)
justification: The methods section notes inclusion of “the Multidimensional Assessment of Interoceptive Awareness ('MAIA').”
“Participants rated their current state on four measures: arousal (denoted as 'alertness'… ) on Likert scales ranging from 1 through 6.”
The same sentence indicates happiness was rated on the identical 1–6 Likert format.
Participants also rated hunger on the 1–6 Likert scale described for state measures.
Thirst was the fourth state rating collected with the same 1–6 Likert instrument.
